Here's a possibility: for any output you want to test, 
  1. run the method 25 times
  2. take the sum of these 25 values
  3. repeat 1 & 2  1000 times overnight
  4. you should have a normal distribution
  5. measure the mean and variance.

Now, when you test, generate 25 instances and compute the sum.  You should
be able to use  a t-test to estimate how "correct" this sum is.  If your
methods spit out multi-modal distributions, I'm not sure how useful the
standard deviation is.

If you really want accurate tests, you should refactor out the component
dependencies and just test the deterministic stuff.

> We're using JUnit to test a evolutionary computation system where many
> (most?) of the methods are directly or indirectly stochastic (use
> random number generation).
> 
> Writing unit tests for the deterministic parts of the system is pretty
> standard fare, but it's not obvious how to reasonably test the
> stochastic parts of the system.  At some level stochastic methods just
> aren't testable in the same way that deterministic methods are.  If
> you're writing a sorting routine, it should sort.  Period.  End of
> discussion.  If, however, you're simulating the roll of a six-sided
> die, then the best you can hope for is statistically plausible
> results, and it's then essentially impossible to tell the difference
> between a bug and a weird streak of luck in the random number
> generator.  (If your die simulation turns up '3' one hundred times in
> a row it's _probably_ a bug, but it might just be a _highly_ unlikely
> event resulting from your pseudo-random number generator.)
> 
> At the moment we've got some hacks where we call methods repeatedly
> (i.e., it's _slow_), and assert that the standard deviation of the
> results is below some arbitrary bound.  The bound was chosen by trial
> and error, running the tests over and over and putting the bound at a
> point where the tests fail about one time in 10.  This is obviously
> cheesy in the extreme.
> 
> Presumably we're not the first people to have wandered into this tar
> pit, and I was wondering if anyone out there had solutions, pointers,
> ideas, etc.
